title: Gareth Southgate seems a bold England boss — and that means international retirement will come early for Wayne Rooney
text:
Sport Opinion Gareth Southgate seems a bold England boss — and that means international retirement will come early for Wayne Rooney It's become blindingly obvious the new manager is moving on without the Three Lions' captain and record scorer Share Sport Opinion Rooney said he'd retire from England next year — Southgate may have brought that forward (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Listening to Gareth Southgate in Dortmund , it was impossible not to assume we saw two retirements in one night at the Signal Iduna Park stadium — the official one marked by a storybook goal and a farewell that could not have been fonder, and the unofficial one unfolding in a Cheshire living room. 
Southgate is moving on without Wayne Rooney . 
That much is now blindingly obvious. 
It was clear from the moment the England boss hinted Rooney might have been fit for Manchester United’s game against Middlesbrough last Sunday (he wasn’t) yet still did not select him in the squad. 
If Southgate thought Rooney might be fit to play at the Riverside then he surely thought he could be fit a week later, when England meet Lithuania at Wembley. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Gareth Southgate speaks after England lose to Germany Share this video Watch Next 
Having given Rooney the clear signal that his England days are probably not so much numbered as over, Southgate then invites him to come along to St George’s Park to listen to a motivational address and maybe wish good luck to the lads in the squad ahead of him. 
Not surprisingly, Rooney chose to stay in Manchester to continue treatment on whatever injury has been stopping Jose Mourinho using him. 
Had Southgate said Rooney was not selected but remained his permanent captain, do you think routine treatment would have kept him away from that meeting in Burton? Of course not. 
No drama, said Southgate, and it wasn’t. 
It was just confirmation that the Rooney era was over. 
Post-game in Dortmund on Wednesday night, there was special praise for those playing in positions Rooney might expect to contend for, across the front three. View gallery Read More 
Praise for how their energy allows them to press. He did not say it… but in a way Wayne cannot. 
Rooney, ill-advisedly, announced last summer he would be retiring from international football after World Cup 2018. 
It looks like Southgate has done it for him well before time. 
Rooney’s nature is such that he will no doubt strive to prove he can still win a 119th cap, wherever he ends up playing his club football next season. He has shown enough determination and bloody-mindedness in his career to suggest he might be able to meet this challenge. 
And don’t forget, in the absence of their record goal-scorer, England failed to score on Wednesday. The attacking players Southgate lavished praise on missed clear opportunities. England were the better side in Dortmund, but without Rooney... (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) ...Dele Alli missed a couple of good chances to score... (Photo: AFP/Getty) ...and Adam Lallana rattled a post... (Photo: PA Wire) ...as Southgate's men lost to the only goal of the night (Photo: Bongarts/Getty Images) Read More 
England are not that well-stocked with attacking options that they can afford to unreservedly discard one, no matter how tired he is looking. 
Southgate, though, is already looking a bold boss. 
He cannot say Rooney is no longer part of the picture, because the player is still available for selection. 
By the very nature of his job, Southgate cannot rule out selecting anyone who qualifies to play. 
Yet the feeling you take from this current England camp is that a line has been drawn. 
Lukas Podolski retired after 130 caps with a wonder-goal on a night of unadulterated adulation. The match was a farewell for Germany forward Lukas Podolski... (Photo: REX/Shutterstock) ...and the former Arsenal man signed off in 'Hollywood ending' style... (Photo: REUTERS) ...with a superb winning goal to mark his 130th and final international cap (Photo: REUTERS) Read More 
One day, maybe Rooney will get that sort of farewell. 
He deserves it, but you would not bank on Southgate allowing it. 
You cannot help feel that in a cold, clinical way, he has already called time on the Wayne Rooney era. poll loading Has Wayne Rooney won his last cap? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
